item.title: Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero Might Make a Case for a More Focused Approach to DB Games
item.description:
Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero has continued to show its love for every corner of the series, with the recent reveal that its final launch roster will feature a whopping 181 fighters. While there's nothing inherently wrong with this, casting such a wide net can have its fair share of downsides as well. Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero repeats one trend with its story mode, and it's one that the next Dragon Ball game would be better off without.

Many Dragon Ball games simply recap events of the anime's story. Dragon Ball is more than iconic enough to warrant a direct adaptation, but the series has returned to the same well far too many times at this point. Furthermore, these games often adapt as much of the anime as possible, and Sparking Zero appears to continue this trend as well. When the next Dragon Ball game inevitably arrives, developers should be sure to narrow their focus.

After Sparking Zero, The Next Dragon Ball Game Needs a More Focused Story

Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero Succeeds at Pure Fan Service

Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero is the upcoming sequel to the beloved Budokai Tenkaichi series, and the resemblance is more than a little apparent. Sparking Zero shares many of its predecessors' priorities, between its jaw-dropping roster size, bombastic action, and even its approach to storytelling. Although many enjoy the similarities between Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero and Budokai Tenkaichi , future games should try a new path.

Dragon Ball: Sparking Zero is a spectacle of fan service first and foremost. Within every aspect of the game, even its marketing before release, this priority is abundantly clear. When it comes to meeting this goal, Sparking Zero succeeds with flying colors. The game manages to capture Dragon Ball in its totality, with its roster and story alike. However, if the next Dragon Ball game wants to leave an impression, one untested approach could hold the secret ingredient.

Future Dragon Ball Games Should Focus On Specific Sagas

Many Dragon Ball games often try to capture as many story arcs as possible, especially when it comes to adapting Dragon Ball Z . By contrast, any story arcs before DBZ are few and far between in most games. Likewise, most Dragon Ball games skip over many major events from GT and Super . Dragon Ball Super has received more attention in recent years, but GT 's controversial status makes its exclusion understandable enough.

There is already a question of how many times players will want to replay a story they've already seen. This question is made that much more pressing when one notices the clear favoritism at play. Regardless, a simple solution could help the series move in a different direction. Instead of attempting to adapt Dragon Ball in its entirety, and losing focus on many important story arcs, future Dragon Ball games could be entirely dedicated to one arc in particular.

The Next Dragon Ball Game Has an Important Choice to Make

Rather than quickly running from one arc to the next, many arcs deserve an entire game in their own right. Many fans have played through the story of Dragon Ball dozens of times across several games, but a more focused story mode could present these arcs in their best state yet. Likewise, developers could eventually give more spotlight to the characters and stories that have drawn the short straw so far.

A game focusing solely on the earliest events of Dragon Ball could be a real treat for fans. After all, it would allow players to fight through a solid adaptation of the tournament that gave the Budokai Tenkaichi series its name. And while the Frieza Saga has been abridged plenty of times at this point, a game focused entirely on the arc could have a dramatic weight not seen in previous adaptations.

Dragon Ball has plenty of iconic stories to pull from, and many of them could be the subject of their own game. Many Dragon Ball protagonists could lead their own game, and Sparking Zero 's What Ifs show the value of original storytelling. However, if Dragon Ball games continue to adapt existing story arcs, they could hugely benefit from a much more narrow focus.

item.title: Starfield Players Running Into 'Lookup Failed' Error
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Starfield players are running into the Lookup Failed error when trying to play the DLC.
  • Some solutions include restarting the console, clearing alternate Mac address, and ensuring the game is updated.
  • It's possible Bethesda will need to issue another update to resolve the issues for some players.

Starfield has just recently launched its Shattered Space DLC, but players trying to get in on the action are running into a "Lookup Failed" error. Starfield has been hyping its Shattered Space DLC for quite some time, teasing players with the chance to explore House Va'ruun's home planet. Unfortunately, the Starfield DLC's release has had some hiccups.

The Starfield subreddit has multiple posts from people who are running into issues trying to access the DLC. For the record, to start the Starfield DLC, players need to have completed the One Small Step quest. At that point, they will have to grav-jump to a system that's not currently being used by any story developments or events. That will get the DLC's story in motion.

The problem is the Lookup Failed error is keeping players from getting Shattered Space started. One Reddit post by Mk18mitch, spotted by Pure Xbox, illustrated the situation. Upon arriving at what is presumably supposed to be Va'ruun'kai, they are instead met with a red and green planet with the words "Default Planet Material. The Swap Hasn't Occurred" plastered on the front of it. The system information on the side of the screen says "Lookup Failed," meaning that the Reddit user will be unable to travel to the planet and continue the DLC until the problem is resolved. Other players have been unable to get the DLC to start at all, possibly due to an error unrelated to "Lookup Failed."

How to Fix the Starfield Lookup Failed Error

Luckily, there may be some solutions to Starfield 's Lookup Failed error. While mileage may vary, some players have reported success after restarting their Xbox consoles. Players may want to clear their alternate Mac address on their consoles to be sure. For some players, they were unable to get the DLC to start because they didn't have the latest update downloaded. Starfield released a new update alongside the DLC (Update 1.14.70), so players should make sure that their game is updated to the latest version before trying to get Shattered Space to work.

Now, it's entirely possible those solutions won't resolve the issue for all Starfield players. Indeed, there are those who claim to have restarted their consoles multiple times and still are unable to play the DLC. If there is some kind of bigger problem keeping Starfield fans from playing the Shattered Space expansion, hopefully a hot fix will be pushed out to address those issues sooner rather than later. In the meantime, Starfield fans can try restarting their system, clearing their alternate Mac address, and making sure that they have the latest update installed.

item.title: Ara: History Untold - How to Win
item.description:
Quick Links

  • How to Win in Ara: History Untold
  • How to Survive the Culling in Ara: History Untold
  • How to Earn Prestige in Ara: History Untold

While some similar strategy games want players to focus on one part of the gameplay in particular, Ara: History Untold incentivizes branching out and rewards gamers for all of their endeavors and accomplishments throughout a match.

When a game of Ara: History Untold comes to an end, there must be a winner, and there is only one way to decide who comes out victorious and is deemed the number one Nation. This guide tells players what they need to know about victory conditions in Ara: History Untold so they can plan out their strategies accordingly.

How to Win in Ara: History Untold

Ara: History Untold games last for three Acts: Act 1, Act 2, and Act 3. Throughout this time, the players will be evaluated based on their feats and receive Prestige accordingly, which will determine their ranking. Here are the rankings by Prestige in Ara: History Untold :

  • Triumphant (Tier 1)
  • Remarkable (Tier 2)
  • Memorable (Tier 3)
  • Forgettable (Tier 4)

The Nations with the least amount of Prestige will fall to the bottom of the ranking system, categorizing 25 percent of the leader pool as "Forgettable". Each time there is an Act change, the Nations in the "Forgettable" section of the Standing leaderboard will lose and be removed from the game.

On the other side of the spectrum, there is the Triumphant and highest ranking; whoever is declared Triumphant by the end of Act 3 (Singularity Era) will be considered the winner of the game in Ara: History Untold . Therefore, to win Ara: History Untold , gamers have to guarantee that they make it to Act 3 by surviving their opponents and the culling, and they must earn enough Prestige to be considered Triumphant once Act 3 ends .

How to Survive the Culling in Ara: History Untold

To avoid falling into the "Forgettable" zone and survive the culling, players must have earned enough Prestige throughout the game to stand above it . Players who are deemed Triumphant, Remarkable, or Memorable are safe and will move forward once the Act comes to an end.

Gamers can disable culling in settings if they'd prefer to not use it in their game; to turn off culling, players have to open the Advanced Settings menu in the Game Setup Options when setting up a new Ara: History Untold game.

How to Earn Prestige in Ara: History Untold

When players start out in Ara: History Untold , they'll only have a total of 2 Prestige: 1 Prestige for founding a city and 1 Prestige for founding a Nation. These two points in particular are associated with the Government category. However, there are accomplishments in other categories that will grant Nation leaders Prestige.

Here are the various categories that need to be taken into consideration when a Nation wants to earn more Prestige and the activities that can generate Prestige:

Category

How to Earn Military Prestige

Prestige-Generating Activities

Military

"Earn Prestige by declaring and winning wars, defeating enemy units, and for turns you have Forces deployed."

  • Research military technologies
  • Complete military Triumphs
  • Win wars
  • Lose Wars (negative)
  • Create Alliances
  • Complete military Act goals
  • Complete military events
  • Defeat units
  • Build military improvements
  • Have standing armies
  • Pillage
  • Denounce Nations

Commerce

"Earn Prestige from Wealth gained each turn and by participating in Trade with other Nations."

  • Research commerce technologies
  • Complete commerce Triumphs
  • Complete commerce Act goals
  • Complete commerce events
  • Build commerce improvements
  • Gain Wealth

Government

"Earn Prestige by founding cities, having high Quality of Life stats each turn, and completing Act goals."

  • Found a Nation
  • Found cities
  • Research government technologies
  • Complete government Triumphs
  • Get a Golden Age
  • Complete government Act goals
  • Build government improvements
  • Have high Quality of Life stats

Religion

"Earn Prestige with an established religion by spreading it between Cities and unlocking Religious Verses."

  • Research religious technologies
  • Complete religious Triumphs
  • Complete religious Act goals
  • Unlock Religious Verses
  • Convert cities
  • Convert Nations
  • Build religious Improvements
  • Religion prevalence
  • Obtain religion Experts

Culture

"Earn Prestige upon completing a Masterpiece and then earn additional Prestige each turn a Masterpiece is displayed as part of a Masterpiece Set."

  • Research cultural technologies
  • Complete cultural Triumphs
  • Complete Masterpieces and Masterpiece Sets
  • Complete cultural Act goals
  • Build cultural Improvements
  • Cultural prevalence
  • Obtain culture Experts

Science

"Earn Prestige each turn for the amount of Research generated toward the unlock of new Technologies."

  • Research technology
  • Complete technological Triumphs
  • Complete technological Act goals
  • Build technological Improvements
  • Research advancement

Industry

"Earn Prestige each turn for the amount of Production utilized to craft goods, harvest resources, and build Improvements."

  • Research production technologies
  • Complete production Triumphs
  • Complete production Act goals
  • Build production Improvements
  • Production strength

Impact

"Earn Prestige by completing Triumphs, building Improvements, claiming Regions, and growing your cities."

  • Research impact technologies
  • Complete goals
  • Claim regions
  • Grow cities

Ultimately, gamers must find a balance in Ara: History Untold , so they can continue to make progress and avoid falling behind when it comes to keeping their cities happy and protected, increasing Wealth and maintaining high production, and generating Research . However, it is up to them to decide if they want to focus on one Prestige category or opt for a more diversified type of gameplay.

item.title: It's Your Last Chance to Claim the Free PS Plus Games for September 2024
item.description:
Key Takeaways

  • Today is the last day to redeem the free PS Plus games for September 2024.
  • PlayStation Plus offers features like exclusive discounts, Share Play, and online multiplayer.
  • Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions, Little Nightmares 2, and MLB The Show 24 will no longer be available to redeem after September 30.

September 30 is the last day that PlayStation Plus members can redeem their three free games for September 2024, as October 2024's monthly games lineup is going live soon. Once claimed, PlayStation Plus members may download and play these titles at any time while maintaining an active subscription at any tier.

Every month, Sony introduces a lineup of monthly free games for PS Plus Essential subscribers. For $79.99 a year, the PS Plus Essential tier also gives subscribers exclusive discounts and content, cloud storage, Share Play functionality, and access to online multiplayer with their favorite games. PS Plus Extra and Premium members may also take advantage of these benefits and redeem their monthly games. The September 2024 batch of PS Plus games consists of Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions , Little Nightmares 2 , and MLB The Show 24 . These three games were first made available to redeem on September 3, and time is quickly running out before the October 2024 lineup goes live on Tuesday, October 1.

Today is the last chance that PS Plus members may redeem Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions , Little Nightmares 2 , and MLB The Show 24 for free on their PlayStation Network account. Players may redeem these titles directly from the PlayStation Store on their PS4 or PS5 consoles and begin to download their games if enough storage space is available. Those away from their console may also redeem the titles by logging into an account with an active PS Plus membership on browsers or the PlayStation mobile app. If a PS4 or PS5 console is synced to the PS app, players may immediately begin to download their PS Plus games to their consoles as well. The app also allows users to browse their entire game library, including past titles they redeemed with PS Plus.

September 30 is the Last Day You Can Redeem the September 2024 Batch of PS Plus Games

  • The lineup includes Harry Potter: Quidditch Champions , Little Nightmares 2 , and MLB The Show 24 .
  • The October 2024 lineup will be available on October 1.

It's worth noting that these games cannot be played if the PS Plus subscription is canceled, however. PlayStation fans will need to renew their PS Plus subscription to regain access to their redeemed games. This applies to titles from the monthly PS Plus Extra and Premium game catalog as well.

Revealed at the September 24 State of Play, the October 2024 batch of PS Plus games includes WWE 2K24 , Dead Space , and Doki Doki Literature Club Plus . PS Plus subscribers may redeem these PS4 and PS5 games from October 1 to November 4. Sony will likely reveal its PS Plus November 2024 monthly games lineup near the end of October.

item.title: Why Persona 6 Could Feel a Lot like Pokemon Gen 5
item.description:
While Persona 6 is rumored to be on the horizon, only speculation and unconfirmed leaks have provided any clues about what to expect from the next entry in Atlus' beloved series. As with each title before, it's at least predicted to usher in a new era for the franchise by defining its own unique theme and aesthetic. In light of recent rumors, however, Persona 6 seems set on exploring themes specifically reminiscent of Pokemon Black and White 's dualistic conflict.

Rumors have previously connected Persona 6 to the color green, but newer speculation has pointed to a new emphasis on black and white, possibly drawing parallels to the Pokemon titles of that namesake. In that series, those fifth-generation titles have been remembered fondly for their exploration of dualism, reflecting the yin and yang concept in one of the most sophisticated stories that Pokemon has featured. If Persona 6 adopts a similar approach for its story as has apparently been leaked, its own conflict could heavily align with Generation 5's thematic core.

The Rumored Emphasis on Duality in Persona 6

Dual Protagonists Could Bring Contrast Front and Center

One of the more striking claims about Persona 6 indicates the inclusion of two player characters in a way that resembles Yakuza 0 's dual protagonists and how they represented contrasting perspectives. According to leaks, these characters might be named Kuro and Shiro, words that literally translate to black and white respectively. Such explicit names would suggest a direct exploration of opposing forces, much like the purpose the Legendaries of Pokemon BW served.

Persona 6's Possible Setting Has Deep Narrative Potential

In a post on X/Twitter, p0wyful stated that P6 will be set within an academic setting familiar to the series, but this time with the twist of being a school focused on the arts:

Through potentially bringing a conflict between these sorts of beliefs or mindsets into Persona as a main theme, it could be inevitable that the game ends up evoking the similar dynamic which was accomplished in Pokemon previously.

Persona 6's Clash Between Modernity and Tradition Could Mirror Pokemon Black and White's Dynamic of Truth Versus Ideals

Using Characters as Symbols in Polarizing the RPG Experience

If the leaks are accurate, Persona 6 has the opportunity to represent opposing philosophical or ideological standpoints through its cast. N and Ghetsis of Pokemon Black and White are two examples of representations of the game's contrasting stances on interacting with Pokemon, liberating them in the name of ideals or using them as tools for truth. If Persona 6 features modernity and tradition for its own themes, the tension between them could easily mirror the grey morality present in Pokemon to create a compelling narrative of its own.

The strategy of releasing two editions of the same basic game set Pokemon BW up for a poignant way to incorporate its theme into every possible aspect of those releases, but Persona 6 would be going even further out of its way for this purpose if its rumors come to be. Naming the protagonists Kuro and Shiro and splitting the single game between them would be a departure from the traditional structure of the series for the sake of emphasizing duality, an effort which could see Persona 6 tackling timeless questions that could remain thought-provoking for years to come.
